The role of the Lord Chancellor has undergone significant changes over time, and these changes have had a significant impact on the UK justice system. Initially, the Lord Chancellor was responsible for running the King's Chancery, which was the legal arm of the monarch's council. Over time, the role expanded to include other legal responsibilities, including the appointment of judges and the administration of the courts.

In 2005, the Constitutional Reform Act was passed, which led to significant changes in the role of the Lord Chancellor. This legislation abolished the Lord Chancellor's role as the head of the judiciary and transferred these responsibilities to the Lord Chief Justice. It also created a new ministry, the Ministry of Justice, which replaced the Lord Chancellor as the head of this department.

This change was made to ensure greater separation of powers between the judiciary and the executive, as well as to modernize the administration of justice in the UK. The reform ensured that the judiciary became fully independent, and that the Lord Chancellor no longer had a role in the appointment of judges or the management of the courts. These responsibilities were transferred to the new Lord Chief Justice of England and Wales.

The impact of these changes has been significant. The separation of powers has ensured that the judiciary is fully independent of the government, and that decisions made by judges are free from political interference. The new arrangement has also ensured that the administration of justice is more modern and efficient, with the Ministry of Justice taking on responsibilities that were previously the remit of the Lord Chancellor. 

Overall, the evolution of the Lord Chancellor's role has reflected changes in society and the way justice is delivered. It has ensured that the UK's legal system remains fit for purpose and is able to adapt to the changing needs of society.
